title: How to learn to do your taxes - Quora

response.answer_text: The hard way. I kept throwing all my receipts in an envelope thinking I’d get around to it later. Only “later” never happened and by then it was too late; so, suddenly, it became extension time and I finally got serious. I was just (still am) a lowly shlub in 1976 with a four-plex and a grunt job for the above so it’s not like I needed a tax lawyer; although someone with a modicum of experience would have been beneficial to keep me for depreciating a $10 item over 7 years using sum-of-the-year-digits. Seriously. I still rationalize that extravagance as being how I taught myself basic accounting. But I didn’t get good at it until LOTUS 123 entered my life (198x.) I sold my four-plex in 1983 and bought a a second or third tier mansion in a previous life which morphed in the 60’s into a 3 floor, 3 kitchen, 4 bathroom, 10 room, 17 bed rooming house and this was when I found out about LOTUS 123. Without LOTUS 123 I would never have been able to keep track of the whole mess. With it, every transaction—cash in, out, or accrual—was recorded using double-entry accounting. One year I used a macro I wrote to meticulously kept track of how long it took me to record every accounting entry. The next year I purposely as an experiment went back to throwing everything in an envelope and then doing it all at once; again keeping track of how much time it took me. Wait for it. 40 hours, either way. Longer than necessary surely; but I was really anal about using LOTUS. A couple of years later my record for actual finalizing and mailing in my taxes was maybe four hours spread over two days because I did such a nice job of separating and categorizing each transaction. The hard part was depreciation. But, damn, my ledger entries and journals were PRETTY. Long story short, I sold my student rental in 1993 and I needed a CPA to sort out how much my net operating loss was over those 11 years. When he saw my LOTUS 123 ledgers and journals he broke out in one of the biggest grins I’ve ever seen. “This will be easy,” he said. I didn’t grin nearly as much when I found out that despite my best efforts I still came in down $9000. Fast forward to 2001 with my broker losing $350,000 in unrealized capital gains in the dot-com meltdown because he knew how to buy but didn’t have a clue about selling in a down market. Back to the CPA again and I haven’t filled out my finalized taxes since. It is cheaper to pay my CPA to handle my Schedule D for 2001 (and the ensuing drawn out trickle down of writing off those stock losses) than it would be to visit a psychologist to keep repairing the damage that would be done if I were forced every year to revisit my inability to know the difference between a genius stock picker and a roaring bull market. Now I have a duplex. I keep track of the ledger entries; transfer everything to the appropriate journals; dummy up my 1040 and Schedule E as best I understand it; turn it all over to my CPA; and I forget about it. He handles all the depreciation. Peace of mind at last for only $200 a year.

Like Jessica Gray, I have filed my own taxes every year since I first had a job. The basic design of the forms tends to stay the same over the years, so you get used to them. I had an income tax class in law school, where some of the general principles of interpretation were discussed. I also had a class in basic accounting in undergraduate school, though I don’t keep books in quite the same form. But mostly I figure my taxes using the instructions to the relevant forms that are provided by the IRS. They’re pretty comprehensive, they’re all easily accessible on the IRS’ web site, and for me they’ve been more than adequate. (Except the ones for Form 4562. Form 4562 is the tenth circle of Hell.) There are also “IRS Publications” that give pointers on more complex topics, and if worse comes to worst, I’ll break out the regulations and read those. That’s quite rare for my own tax return, but occasionally I encounter a client who needs some direction with regard to a strange issue. If I had something more complicated than a sole proprietorship where I use a straight-up cash accounting method, I might seek the assistance of someone who is in fact an expert in the matter.

On a Monday morning in March 1971, Mr. Lechowicz, my Eight Grade mathematics teacher, distributed copies of the IRS 1040 instruction book, blank Federal 1040 Forms from that year, and a mimeographed fact sheet of his financial particulars. A packet was handed out to each of the 28 students in the class. Our homework, his prepared return, was due that Friday. No classroom instruction. It’s just a big word problem, folks. A typical American do-it-yourselfer tiptoes into the intricacies of the tax code over many years. There’s not a whole lot to deal with the extent of your finances is a summer job stocking shelves in a grocery store or washing dishes at a restaurant. The fact that the first few sentences about things like “S-Corporations” seems utterly opaque is your assurance that the line does not apply. If some of the wording of a line-by-line instruction seems to make it possible it applies to you, then read the paragraph. Yes, sometimes you need to jump to another form. But back in the day, that meant a trip to the post office or library with the racks of forms and instruction booklets they put out every winter. Now they are all PDF’s online. The extra forms and schedules take years to accumulate. Save your work from prior years. I recommend a high-level functional read-through of the Form 1040 and key schedules, and review of the instruction booklet before using tax preparation software. Definitely check the first part of the instructions that provide an overview and highlight the changes from the prior year. Major newspapers, those primitive paper and ink website mock-ups, also run a multi-page walk-through of the major forms and schedules, every spring.

For me, it was simple. I read the instructions for the forms my parents used. But this was pretty simple, as they were wage earners with the most common deductions -- home mortgage, property tax, charitable contributions. I've read over instructions for forms I didn't need but was curious about, most notably schedules C, D, and SE. The instructions around depreciation and cost of goods sold, I am sure I would have to read much more closely if I found myself in a position where I needed to file information about those. In more recent years I have on occasion needed a schedule D, but I don't worry about it any more, software does it for me.

Unless you plan on being a tax professional, there is no reason why you should do your own taxes. If you just have a w-2 and a mortgage, just use one of the online programs and answer the questions it asks you. If your return is any more complicated than that, find a good professional tax preparer. They don't have to be a CPA but at least an Enrolled Agent who is registered with the IRS. If you've got a friend, co-worker, or boss that is financially successful, ask them who they use and follow suit.

I started doing my taxes by hand in high school when it was just a single page 1040EZ. The instructions are detailed and very clearly written for this particular document. You can look up all forms and instructions for free at the Internal Revenue Service website. After college and moving to a real 1040 I was having to learn 1–3 new things a year. I only switched to using Turbo Tax around the time I turned 30. If you want something more formal, tax preparation companies typically offer training at low cost in the summer and fall as part of their recruitment practices. Income Tax Course

Generally speaking, reading and practice. I had always done my in taxes. Started out in paper forms and moved to computer based abd then e-filing. When I started my business I continued doing my taxes but when I went from some proprietorship to a s-corp my convinced me to use an accountant. I did that for a few years but then finally fired them. Why? Because they basically were just using the same tax software everyone else does. Even worse, they would call and ask me specific questions even though they had complete access to my books as well as my personal financial information. I took them back and have handled them ever since. The last couple of years have been a but complicated because we my wife had a salaried position, a sole proprietorship, and I had a salary as well as pass through income from my business. I am also filing corporate taxes. It takes about 10 hours each year for both returns. Most if that is looking up information and double checking. I will say without the web I would not attempt it. You need this resources, especially all those IRS publications at your finger tips.

H&R Block has an excellent tax class as well as continuing education for a minimal fee. H&R Block started the entire tax preparation business and is well resourced and training heavy based. The tax class is free. You just pay for the 2–3 inch text book and 2–3 inch workbook that accompanies the textbook. I've taken the 72+ hour class and knowing what I know now I wouldn't trust anyone else to do taxes except those who have done this class or one similar to it. I cringe at those who say I had my friend or aunt do my taxes because it's free. It's an audit waiting to happen.

I paid to have it done once, and then I used that as a basic outline for how I’d do my taxes the next year. I also went through the full list of IRS Form 1040 schedules (Schedules for Form 1040) as well as those for my state, and I checked if any applied to me. If you have a personal business (Small Business Forms and Publications) or other significant type of income/expense (college, mortgages, stocks, etc.), I’d definitely look those up carefully as well. The U.S. tax code might seem scary at first, but 90% of it won’t apply to you anyway. If you have the time, it’s definitely helpful to save yourself money instead of getting a tax preparer. On the other hand, if you don’t enjoy doing taxes or don’t have the time to learn and look things up, it may be worth it to pay someone else (time is money, after all).

A2A - Personal or business? Personal - you can go to H&R Blocks 10 week */- tax school for free and learn how to do taxes their way which would qualify to work for them for $10/hour +/-. You MIGHT be qualified to do a basic 1040 with no complications on it. Business - frankly you MUST understand accounting. That means a bachelors degree in Accounting plus another 30 hours of college beyond that JUST to be qualified to sit for the CPA exam. Then after spending 5–10 years working for a CPA you MIGHT be qualified to prepare business tax returns. It can and usually is that complicated.

Personal taxes are easy - there’s not much to learn, only pay $10 online for a service to do it all for you: you have to type in some numbers, but without much complicated accounting, it’s a breeze. For corporate taxes, I learned from the CPA that did those taxes - compiling schedules, verifying estimates (annual asset valuations), obtaining needed forms from relevant investment brokerages, and accounting basically for every single penny that the business spent (this mostly happens throughout the year, otherwise it’s just one daunting task that can take weeks). Once all the books are in order and all accounts are reconciled, it’s just a matter of plugging numbers in and checking that there are receipts to substantiate transactions.Well, that and my love of accounting - and special care towards keeping it all in order (I love details and reconciliations, you know).

Everything you need to learn in order to be an expert in taxes is on the internet. There are no secrets. It is just a matter of reading and deciding just how much you wish to learn. If you read the IRS tax code from cover to cover, for example, that’s 73,000 pages worth or reading. Articles published can give the lay person a decent overview and understanding of taxes without having to spend the new five years of your life reading about specifics that don’t really apply to you. I’d also recommend trying to get an overview about the different types of taxes which may include things like: personal income taxes (federal and state)sales and use taxesproperty taxespayroll related taxesretirement related taxes (medicare and FICA)business related taxesexcise taxesfranchise taxesOne you’ve found an area that interest you, you can always dig further into finding out more and, in the extreme, reading the tax code itself. Good luck with your studies.

If you want to learn how to do your own taxes with a pen & a form I suggest taking one of the many tax prep classes out there. While you won’t learn some of the more complicated stuff you will get a healthy understanding o the basics. If you have more complicated stuff, like rentals then I suggest that you find a patient preparer & ask a lot of questions. Pay attention to the questions being asked and lean how the answers impact your return. You can also find various publications for various things on the IRS website. These are free and you can read your heart out. Good luck GetATMEtaxprep.com

Nowadays it is pretty easy. You get a text message from the tax authorities with the information they have. For most people every data is correct and just accept. If you need to do some changes you just log in and make any changes. Even if you own shares on the stock market it is pretty easy. If in doubt you can chat in real time. All this goes for Sweden. Don't know how it works in other country, but it is pretty straightforward.

There are many ways to learn to do your taxes. You could hire your accountant and they could guide you through it. You could Google it. You could ask friends. The most important thing is to read the directions on each form to make sure you’re doing it correctly.

Is it pretty easy to learn how to do your own taxes? Depends on how complicated they are. If it's just a straight short form 1040 just follow the instructions in the book. If you are going more complicated than that buy a tax program for your computer and have at it. Most of the time you're better off going to a paid professional. Especially if you own a business or your taxes are complicated in some way.

If you are simply a W-2 employee, most software programs will give you a ‘tax-preparation-by-numbers’-type experience. More complicated taxes require a more in depth understanding of the tax law. I know a 60-year old woman who passed all three exams for becoming an IRS Enrolled Agent in 90 days.
I went to university and studied the tax code under a former revenue agent (basically an IRS Agent who carries a gun) who knew the tax code by heart.
If you can follow the directions on a packet of cake mix, you can do your own taxes- unless your financials are very involved indeed.

The free way in Singapore is to visit the website of the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore because it provides free information. Other ways could be to attend tax training organised by professional bodies or similar organisations.

If you want to read plain English version of the IRC buy this handbook; quick finder by Thomson Reuters get the standard version. Read the whole thing it should take a day. It will give you a good start
Start by doing your own return - if you think you have a feel for it - try to get a seasonal job with H & R Block or Jackson Hewitt.
